seg.seg: When (the kings out of insatiability) lead (the army) into (other) countries, they kill many beings. Not there are the ten good deeds, the Yakṣas obtain power [and] kill many beings. When the Nāgas see the perverted passions [and] (leave) the countries, the waters dry up, of hunger the beings
Wenn die Nāgas die verkehrten Leidenschaften sehen [und] die Länder (verlassen), trocknen die Wasser aus, an Hunger sterben die Wesen, [und] dieser Jambudvīpa geht zugrunde.
When the Nāgas see the wrong passions [and] (leave) the lands, the waters dry up, the beings die of hunger, [and] this Jambudvīpa perishes.

die, [and] this Jambudvīpa perishes. [87d]. Maudgalyāyana after that (revealed to) Jātiśrona at length, how life passes away. “(Just as) the earthen vessels, however many the potter will shape, (are) all ending with the fracturing,
[Just] (as) earthenware bowls, no matter how many the potter fashions, all [have] breaking [as their] end, …

so [also] the live and body of the beings shaped by the potter “Karman”; even [when] preserved with care, death is (the end) of all. [88d] (Just like the herdsman) goads his cows with a stick, and ever drives them to their corrals, in this way old age and death
(So wie der Hirt seine) Kühe mit dem Stock bedroht [und] sie je zu ihren Hürden führt, auf solche Weise bedrohen Alter [und] Tod das Leben der Wesen [und] führen es seinem Ziel zu.

(Just like the herdsman) threatens (his) cows with a stick [and] leads them each to their paddocks, in such a way, old age [and] death threaten the life of the beings [and] lead it to its [ultimate] destination.
goad the life of the beings and drive it to its destination. Just like a mountain stream .... (does not) turn back, so lives go by and do never turn back.” [89d] When he had heard this, the Brahman
Wie der Bergstrom ... (nicht) umkehrt, so gehen die Leben vorüber und kehren nicht wieder um.
Like the mountain stream ... (does not) turn back, just so the lives go past and do not turn back again.

lost his (pleasure) in life, and his view on his own self disappeared in him. Again at another (time) the Omniscient (the Master, was staying in Śrāvastī), in the beautiful palace of the Mṛgārā. Many monks sat there in conversation: “A miracle

[is] this, short [is] the life of humans, [but], the beings[are] (here) without zeal, they do not evoke aversion for the world.” [90d] The Buddha heard the(ir) conversation with divine (ears). (He came in/through the air) to the place, [and] the Buddha asked the monks: “What conversation were you sitting in?” They told [it]
Es fragte der Buddha die Mönche: "Bei welchem Gespräch saßet ihr?"
The Buddha asked the monks: "What conversation were you sitting in?"

the Omniscient. The Master praised them in many ways and recounted to them an earlier conversation at length: (Kau)ravya by name (was a king here in the Jambudvīpa). [91d] Supratiṣṭhita by name (was) a Nyagrodha, a king of the trees, in his land of five tree boughs,

a great one. They ate his fruit – and sweet was [its] (taste, like honey) in taste – on the great branches of the boughs; from the first bough of the trees (the king, from the second [his] followers), from (the third) the country people, from the fourth bough those that had gone from the house, from the fifth bough the animals

[92d] They did not eat each other. [It was] fruit the animals (ate) at that time, they did not do wrong. This king (however) had a Brahman there (Araṇemi by name), wise and compassionate. The life of humans was six myriads of years [long],
Sie fraßen sich nicht gegenseitig.
They did not eat each other.

[but] Araṇemi's deliberation was: “Evil is the life of humans now, [but] they do not evoke aversion for the world.” [93d] Fearing (life), he went from the house ... with spirit (filled with aversion for the world). Numberless thousands and myriads
Übel [ist] jetzt das Leben der Menschen, [aber] sie bringen nicht Lebensüberdruss hervor.
Evil now [is] the life of humans, [but] they do not call forth life-.weariness.

of beings went from the house with Araṇemi. Under the Nyagrodha-tree he always stayed, there he recited the law to the students. The unreliability of life (he discussed): [94d] The life of humans is now
Unter dem Nyagrodhabaum hielt er [scil. Araṇemi] sich ständig auf, dort trug er den Schülern das Gesetz vor.
Under the Nyagrodha-tree he [i.e. Araṇemi] always stayed, there he recited the law to the students.

only short (as) a drop of dew on the tips of grasses. Like (the tongues) of the snakes, like the ear of the elephant, as flexible ... ... Araṇemi, the teacher, recited to his students. Having carefully pricked up the ears, in life
Vertraut nicht auf das Leben!
Do not trust in life!

do not trust . [95d] Just like the thread strechted here, as often as it is interwoven with the plait ... such [is] here the life of humans; however many are alive, in the passing of days and months it will only be cut off afterwards.
[Just] as the thread stretched here: as much as it is woven with the woof, so much smaller it becomes. (cf : ii, 7)

Wie hier der aufgezogene Faden, wie oft er mit dem Einschlag verwebt wird, (so oft gering[er] wird), so [ist] hier das Leben der Menschen, wieviele auch leben, im Vergehen der Tage und Monate wird es hinterher nur abgeschnitten.

Like the taut thread here, [that,] as often as it is interwoven with the plait, (gets less as often), just so [is] the life of humans here, how ever many [there] live, in the passing of days and months it is but cut off afterwards.

[Just] as a being here, being led to be killed: as many steps as it takes to the killing place [lit. cemetery], with so many it (approaches)301 death. So the life of humans (is destroyed). (cf : ii, 7)

Just like a being being led to the killing (here), however many steps it goes to the place of death, (it comes?) closer to death, so the life of humans (passes). [96d] The life [of humans] [is] difficult and only short, and it involves suffering, but the beings do not realize [it].
Das Leben [der Menschen ist] schwierig [und] nur gering, und es ist mit Leid verbunden, aber die Wesen merken [es] nicht.
Life [of humans is] difficult [and] only [of] little [value(?)], and it is accompanied by suffering, but the beings do not realise [this].
Wie der Stockstreich im Wasser vergeht in einem Augenblick, so vergeht das Leben der Menschen.
Just like a blow with a stick fades in the water within a moment, so fades human life.

Like the streak of a stick into water fades within a moment, so fades the life of humans. The life [of humans] has (no) stability, and suddenly (suffering) and poverty comes, cuts off the hope of humans and destroys all wishes. [97d]
Und plötzlich kommt Leid [und] Armut, schneidet die Hoffnung der Angehörigen ab [und] vernichtet alle Wünsche.
And suddenly there comes suffering [and] poverty, cuts off the hope of the relatives [and] destroys all wishes.

(Such) strophes (it was that) Araṇemi at that (time) recited to the students, [and] (many) grew weary of life there. Six myriads of years [lasted] the life of the people, [but] only little was [it] worth to them, they went from the house into poverty. Now life is (just) short

correponds to Uv I, 17: yathā daṇḍena gopālo gāḥ prāpayati gocaram evaṃ rogair jarā mṛtyuḥ āyuḥ prāpayate nṛṇām
corresponds to Uv I, 15: yathā nadī pārvatīyā gacchate na nivartate evaṃ āyur manuṣyāṇāṃ gacchate na nivartate
corresponds to Uv. I, 13: yathāpi tantre vitate yad yad uktaṃ samupyate alpaṃ bhavati vātavyam evaṃ martyasya jīvitam
corresponds to Uv. I, 14 which is only partially attested in Sanskrit: yathāpi va ˘ ˉ ˉ ˉ ˚˚˚˚˘ ˉ ˘ ˉ ˚ghatano bhavati evaṃ martyasya jīvitam
Cf. the Tibetan version: dper na ṅes par bsad pa dag || gom pa gaṅ daṅ gaṅ bor bas ||
It is with the life of mortal man as with (the spider), who, though it would free itself from its trap, finds, whichever way it takes a step, the abode of death before it?
corresponds to Uv. I, 16: kisaraṃ ca parittaṃ ca tac ca duhkhena samyutam udake daṇḍarājīva kṣipram eva vinaśyati
